channel.title: Jessie Ren
channel.description: Write an awesome description for your new site here. You can edit this line in _config.yml. It will appear in your document head meta (for Google search results) and in your feed.xml site description.

item.title: Optimizely Stats Engine
item.description:
Stats Engine, a newly patented statistical framework for A/B testing, makes Optimizely the first of all A/B testing products in the market to provide always-valid experiment results, eliminating the need to wait to check results and to set sample sizes. To promote this landmark product change, Optimizely launched an educational campaign—I focused on designing the “resources” landing page and an ebook.

Storytelling with a Persona


Originally, we wanted to create a fun & educational video about Stats Engine as part of the campaign launch. I quickly threw together some storyboards about our persona Tom, who’s an A/B testing hero at his company, and a scenario about how statistics affects his job. Unfortunately, this project was cut—however, the process helped the team see value in how this product change could affect our customers. By creating this persona and scenario, we were able to pull out important questions like:

  • —“How does Stats Engine effect Tom?”
  • —“Why should Tom care about stats?”
  • —“How much stats would Tom know off-hand?”

These questions helped answer and guide much of the content creation on the landing page, which went through several iterations.

Initial analog storyboard

Digital storyboards with captions

Wireframe iterations

Designing content together

We broke traditional work silos with this landing page by having content and design work in parallel. I was lucky to work with a collaborative content team! We sat together in a room and wrote down the goals of the page, aligned on a voice & tone, and nailed down the structure of the page—all the essentials of a brief done in a 20 minute meeting. Together, we combed through the initial drafts of copy and decided on accompanying visuals. Most importantly, we had

a theme and a story to tell for the page. I suggested the concept/theme of old vs. new and it stuck. Many A/B testing platforms are still using traditional statistics (old), so by talking about the old, we were able to really showcase the new Stats Engine. This leant itself to visuals like analog drafting tools you don’t use often such as calculators next to digital tools you use all the time such as a laptop.

Traditional vs New concept

Results before Stats Engine

Results with Stats Engine

Stats Engine helps correct a number of statistical errors, and we wanted to show that visually. The big error stats engine corrects for is “continuous monitoring”, or peeking at your results before reaching statistical significance. The left graph shows volatility while the right graph shows stability.

Instead of creating two graphics, I proposed combining the two to make one, easily shareable graphic. (Below) With some statistician assistance, I overlayed the two graphs, matching the data points as closely as possible.


A credible look and feel

Optimizely is still a young product on the market, so a big factor in the visual design was maintaining a credible and trustworthy look and feel that aligns with the “branding” of our marketing site. As a designer, I pride myself on restraint, but this page was challenging. Selfishly, I wanted it to look

exciting, to show off how cool our stats are with animation, scroll effects, and bright, new colors. But with constraints like localization, potential evergreen content, responsiveness, and 72 hours, I kept the page as clean as possible. The page received over 7,000 views in 2 days, check it out!

item.title: Sketches
item.description: Pulled from the depths of my artboards.

item.title: Partner Program
item.description: Optimizely is launching a new Partners Program. I designed a few landing pages as part of the launch (coming soon). We're also working on developing an illustration style to be used on the marketing site —below are some in-progress shots of the graphics for the page.

item.title: Optimizely One-offs
item.description:
Here’s the small collection of some fun one-off stuff I did at Optimizely.

Optiverse Icons

Optiverse is Optimizely’s community support and knowledge base for all things related to testing. Optimizely Academy is a hub for taking courses on how to use Optimizely. I designed some icons to show each course level.

.

Exploring different metaphors. The first row deals with the concept of space and atomic physics (disclaimer on the accuracy of the depiction as I admit to knowing very little about the topic). The second and third row have to do with the evolution of flight and fire respectively.

The first concept was chosen because the style could scale when more courses are added and is seen implemented above.

Optimizely 200 employees shirt

I was the 201st employee hired at Optimizely. Even though I was only at the company for 4 months, so much had happened! I wanted to highlight internal milestones of that year. MC Commerce debuted, we raised our Series B, had our first user conference…what better than to showcase our company "mascot" on a $200 bill with the company logo in the background?

item.title: Optimizely Opticon Conference
item.description:
Opticon is Optimizely’s annual user conference. For 2015, we chose to brand the event in-house. It’s still a work in progress, so I’ll be updating the page when the project is complete. For now, I’m posting some process shots of my contributions.

Word dump turned word map.

Animating some tests.

Where the concept was born.

Some track icons

item.title: Optimizely Mobile Onboarding
item.description:
Optimizely for mobile allows you to A/B test your mobile apps. I helped with the visual design of the mobile onboarding experience. Since it’s one of the first things a customer sees when she signs up, we wanted the visual design to be on brand.

Before

After

To start using the product, all you need to do is install the Optimizely for Mobile SDK. You can either install the code snippet yourself or send the instructions to someone else.

Before

After

Installing the SDK yourself.

Before

After

Emailing SDK install instructions.

item.title: Optimizely Mobile Landing Page
item.description:
Optimizely for mobile is just that, A/B testing for mobile apps done through a web interface. For this campaign, I designed a product marketing landing page. The goal of the page was to get as many signups for beta as possible.

Initial wireframe prototype showing interactions and scroll effects on the page.

Showcasing product features

We wanted to showcase features of the mobile product in an interactive way, similar to a demo “try before you buy”, on the page. However, building out that kind of interactivity can be really resource intensive. We decided to try making “videos” of the product features instead. I came up with some testing

ideas using Airbnb’s app as an example, since we’d gotten good customer feedback about trusting Airbnb as an example. Although the page was originally designed for our iOS beta launch, I wanted to keep the phones neutral so we could reuse the graphics for our Android launch as well.

1. Making visual changes with the WYSIWYG Editor

Say you want to test connected sign-ins and predict that more users will login through Facebook than Google. You can drag and drop the FB login button to the top of the screen.

2. Making code level changes with developer tools

Say you want to be able to test app engagement with and without a login screen. Using developer tools, you can custom create an on/off switch for a login screen.

3. Instantly roll out changes.

Now that you have a couple of variations to test, you can deploy the changes without having to go through an appstore review. In this example we show the two test variations we made through the WYSIWYG editor and Developer Tools.

The two animated viedos that didn't make the cut.

Hacking the header image

We needed a specific header image that was difficult to find so we made our own using free stock photos and a customized app screen. Though it was a bit hacky, this allowed us to have complete control over the header image as well as provide a reusable process for future product marketing pages.

First step was finding an nicely photoshopped hand holding a phone, then add your own screen. Second step was finding a stock photo to put it on.

Create the illusion of depth of field by blurring the stock photo behind the photoshopped hand holding a phone.

Blur the entire image, just as you might with any stock photo you want to put text over.

Overlay a brand color on the image to make the treatment specific to your company’s.

Animated gif timing logic

Animations and videos can really affect page performance. When building out the page, we decided on gifs (similar to InVision) due to file sizes and talked through the timing of when the gifs play as you’re scrolling down the page as well as how that’d translate on mobile since there aren’t hover states. Check out the page and see how we did it. Mockup of the final site below.

item.title: Optimizely Ebooks
item.description:
Designed various ebooks for Optimizely. The Experience Optimization Playbook is Optmizely’s most downloaded ebook, with 800+ downloads within the first 24 hours of launching. Below are some pages from the ebook.

Statistics Ebook

This ebook was part of the Stats Engine educational campaign launch.

item.title: Burn-the-Lot
item.description: Completed while interning at Propaganda3 in Kansas City. I designed uv textures and graphics for the in-house mobile app game Burn the Lot. Helped develop the visual theme for the punk carnival aesthetic under the creative direction of Cameron Calder. Assets included posters, character outfits, and various objects.
